NovÃ¡ scÃ©nickÃ¡ vÃ½prava je dÃ­lem anglickÃ©ho scÃ©nografa Petera Horna, kostÃ½my navrhl vÃ½tvarnÃ­k Roman Å olc.ObnovenÃ¡ premiÃ©ra: 19. Ãºnora 2019 v JanÃ¡ÄkovÄ› divadle,The immortal story that is synonymous with the word ballet.Swan Lake is one of the worldâ€™s most performed and famous ballets.The motives of Scandinavian folk tale and legend about a girl cursed to be a swan inspired Tchaikovsky to write this lyrical music. Music that later became the greatest example of a romantic ballet score. Princess Odette is enchanted by Baron Rothbart into a swan and can be saved only by true love. Prince Siegfried, who promised to love her, later betrays her and the curse remains unbroken, even though Odette eventually forgives the unhappy Prince. Swan Lake is now admired by generations of viewers and creators alike. Dancers are trying to eagerly match with the ambitious ballet technique. This production is staged with the traditional choreography by Marius Petipa and Lev Ivanov. It was staged by the long-term Ballet Master of the prestigious Italian theatre La Scala, Robert Strajner, who made the storyline clearer and added directorial concept. By highlighting the clarity of style and form, Swan Lake by Ballet NdB continues PetipaÊ¼s and IvanovÊ¼s legacy, enriched by western European tradition in Strajner.The restored premiere of this eternal story by Tchaikovsky was a significant event for Ballet NdB as it took place almost to the exact day of its world premiere in Brno, a hundred years ago. After twenty years in the NdB repertoire, set of this great production was completely re-designed. Exceptional financial support from out founder allowed us to work with renowned artists and further expand your experience of this legendary ballet piece. The new set design of this restored production is a work of an excellent English set designer, Peter Horne, who has also designed the set for The Nutcracker. Costumes are designed by Roman Å olc, who has been working alongside the Ballet NdB for more than 20 years now. He is one of the most wanted costume designers in the Czech dance world.Renewed premiere: 19th of February 2019 at JanÃ¡Äek Theatre

Jejich osudy se tak stÃ¡vajÃ­ modelovÃ½mi pÅ™Ã­klady, kterÃ© je moÅ¾no analogicky sledovat i v rÃ¡mci globÃ¡lnÃ­ ekonomiky.,The Made by Fire exhibition commemorates the 150th anniversary of the founding of The Museum of Applied Arts of The Moravian Gallery in Brno.Experience the power and fragility of Bohemian glass and porcelain in their trial by fire.Glass and porcelain are somewhat of a national treasure. They have a long tradition and a unique place in Czech culture. But what do these terms mean today?Faced with one crisis after another â€“ social, ecological and geopolitical â€“ does it still make sense to develop glass and porcelain into the future?We believe it does, and we are convinced that the disclaimer â€œMade in Czechiaâ€œ has a bright future ahead, both with standard factories as well as small art studios.All 50+ original works featured as part of the exhibition have a common origin â€“ their glass, porcelain and ceramics were made in the fires of Czech furnaces and kilns. We selected pieces from prestigious glass producers and exporters, the foremost porcelain works, the major players on the design scene, as well as the up-and-coming generation of designers whose work it pays to follow.The exhibition will take you through four thematic sections: Industry â†’, Adaptation â†’, Identity â†’ and Experiment â†’.You will encounter works which test the limits of applied art and deal with contemporary social problems, such as industry competitiveness, its environmental impact, the use of classical forms, and the implementation of new technologies.

column2: The intention of the exhibition of Marius Kotrba is to present the lifetime sculptural and painting work of this important personality of Czech art culture at the turn of the 20th and 21st centuries, with the aim of comprehensively capturing his extraordinary artistic legacy.Works from all areas of the artist’s oeuvre will be selected for the retrospective exhibition, with an emphasis on their connections. From the early period, the central theme of Kotrbas’ work remained the human being; he was inspired by actual stimuli based on everyday life, personal experiences, and civil themes symbolizing interpersonal relationships. In his work he focused on spiritual values influencing human existence. In his work, one can observe the development of expressive means and morphology, the tendency towards a lapidary simplification of forms, without losing the subject matter. Tension and emotional charge are inherent in all areas of his work – sculptures, reliefs, paintings and drawings. By concentrating on the essential and focusing on intensity, Kotrba achieved general validity and timeless values in his works.The exhibition will highlight the main aspects of his lifelong artistic direction not only within the Czech cultural scene, but also in the context of the development of European art since the 1980s. This approach will be made possible by the collaboration with the experienced Viennese curator Berthold Ecker. For the first time, a new perspective on Kotrba’s work will be provided, not only in the context of Czech art culture. The project will make public the circumstances that led to the creation of the sculpture Justice, which stands in front of the Administrative Court in Brno, as well as a number of sculptures for the city centre that were only considered but not realised.The exhibition will be accompanied by a monographic publication created in collaboration with the Gallery of Fine Arts in Ostrava, the Gallery of the Capital City of Prague and the House of Arts of the City of Brno.The exhibition is held under the auspices of the Mayor of the City of Brno, Mrs. MarkÃ©ta VaÅˆkovÃ¡, and Governor of the South Moravian Region, Mr. Jan Grolich.The main media partner of the exhibition is ÄŒeskÃ¡ televize (Czech Television).,ZÃ¡mÄ›rem soubornÃ© vÃ½stavy Maria Kotrby je pÅ™edstavit celoÅ¾ivotnÃ­ sochaÅ™skÃ© a malÃ­Å™skÃ© dÃ­lo tÃ©to vÃ½znamnÃ© osobnosti ÄeskÃ© vÃ½tvarnÃ© kultury pÅ™elomu 20. a 21. stoletÃ­ s cÃ­lem komplexnÄ› postihnout jeho mimoÅ™Ã¡dnÃ½ umÄ›leckÃ½ odkaz.Pro retrospektivnÃ­ vÃ½stavnÃ­ soubor byly vybrÃ¡ny prÃ¡ce ze vÅ¡ech oblastÃ­ umÄ›lcovy tvorby s dÅ¯razem na jejich souvislosti. column2: Meeting Brno 2024 â€“ From Trauma to HopeBury the unpleasant past? Sometimes it can seem like an appealing option. But historical events live on in stories passed down from generation to generation. In less obvious ways, we pass them on even in silence, and they affect the present and ourselves profoundly more than we realise. Let us untangle these strands and face the reality. Together we can move towards healing â€“ and towards new hopeâ€¦Over the ten days of the festival we will offer a programme of discussions, exhibitions, lectures, concerts, theatre productions, film screenings, workshops, walks and marches. Come and experience encounters with great personalities of our present and past, with places and their memory, with artistic creations and most importantly with other people. Be moved by powerful stories and allow the encounters to change you.Meeting Brno 2024 â€“ because everything starts with an encounter.The Meeting Brno festival is held under the auspices of the governor of South Moravia, Mr Jan Grolich, and the mayor of Brno, Dr MarkÃ©ta VaÅˆkovÃ¡.The project is financially supported by the City of Brno, the South Moravian Region, the Ministry of Culture, the Czech-German Future Fund and the Embassy of the Federal Republic of Germany in Prague.,Podtitul: Cena (s)mÃ­ru Festival Meeting Brno 2025 oslavÃ­ svÅ¯j jubilejnÃ­ 10. roÄnÃ­k s ÃºstÅ™ednÃ­m tÃ©matem 80. vÃ½roÄÃ­ od konce druhÃ© svÄ›tovÃ© vÃ¡lky. column2: International competition for the next building of the Moravian Jewish Museum Mehrin four world leading studios: the Bjarke Ingels Group (DK), MVRDV (NL), Cino Zucchi Architetti (IT) and Kengo Kuma & Associates (JP).The nine-member jury, headed by architect Josef Pleskot, finally unanimously awarded the the victory to the Japanese architect, who, according to her, offered the “greatest content andformal openness’, thus most accurately meeting the expectations of the contracting authority.Our permanent exhibition offers several large-scale visualisations of the design as well as a 3D model.There is also a very interesting interview with architect Kengo Kuma, who gave us an interview before the opening of the exhibition of competition designs at the Architecture Gallery in Brno and where he talks about why he chose this solution for Brno, but also more generally about the functions that the museum should fulfil in the 21st century.,MezinÃ¡rodnÃ­ soutÄ›Å¾e o pÅ™Ã­Å¡tÃ­ budovu MoravskÃ©ho Å¾idovskÃ©ho muzea Mehrin se zÃºÄastnily ÄtyÅ™i pÅ™ednÃ­ svÄ›tovÃ© ateliÃ©ry: Bjarke Ingels Group (DK), MVRDV (NL), Cino Zucchi Architetti (IT) a Kengo Kuma & Associates (JP). column11: International competition for the next building of the Moravian Jewish Museum Mehrin four world leading studios: the Bjarke Ingels Group (DK), MVRDV (NL), Cino Zucchi Architetti (IT) and Kengo Kuma & Associates (JP).The nine-member jury, headed by architect Josef Pleskot, finally unanimously awarded the the victory to the Japanese architect, who, according to her, offered the “greatest content andformal openness’, thus most accurately meeting the expectations of the contracting authority.Our permanent exhibition offers several large-scale visualisations of the design as well as a 3D model.There is also a very interesting interview with architect Kengo Kuma, who gave us an interview before the opening of the exhibition of competition designs at the Architecture Gallery in Brno and where he talks about why he chose this solution for Brno, but also more generally about the functions that the museum should fulfil in the 21st century.

column2: This year, the traditional exhibition of nativity scenes will be presented in a completely different version in the MitrovskÃ½ Summer Palace in Brno.Instead of the classic and well-known nativity scenes of Czech, Moravian, or Slovak ones, we will show visitors how different nativity scenes look in other European countries (e.g. in Austria, Germany, Italy, Portugal â€“ Madeira, Poland, etc.). Examples of nativity scenes from other continents – from overseas – will be relatively rare. That you have never seen a nativity scene from Africa? You have no idea what a nativity scene from Mexico or Peru looks like? And what about the hipster nativity scene from the USA… There is also a Christian population living in Asia, so there will be a few examples from these distant parts. And are there kangaroos and koalas in the Australian nativity scene? Part of the presentation of European countries will be the well-known Saxon floor pyramids or popular nutcrackers, and the interesting structure of the nativity scene made of olive wood from Israel.Classic European nativity scenes from a cultural environment close to us will be complemented by nativity scenes from Latin America – Mexico, Peru or Bolivia, influenced by the art of South American Indians. column11: This year, the traditional exhibition of nativity scenes will be presented in a completely different version in the MitrovskÃ½ Summer Palace in Brno.Instead of the classic and well-known nativity scenes of Czech, Moravian, or Slovak ones, we will show visitors how different nativity scenes look in other European countries (e.g. in Austria, Germany, Italy, Portugal â€“ Madeira, Poland, etc.). Examples of nativity scenes from other continents – from overseas – will be relatively rare. That you have never seen a nativity scene from Africa? You have no idea what a nativity scene from Mexico or Peru looks like? And what about the hipster nativity scene from the USA… There is also a Christian population living in Asia, so there will be a few examples from these distant parts. And are there kangaroos and koalas in the Australian nativity scene? Part of the presentation of European countries will be the well-known Saxon floor pyramids or popular nutcrackers, and the interesting structure of the nativity scene made of olive wood from Israel.Classic European nativity scenes from a cultural environment close to us will be complemented by nativity scenes from Latin America – Mexico, Peru or Bolivia, influenced by the art of South American Indians. These nativity scenes are colorfully painted and artisans make them from different materials â€“ ceramics, stone, wood or fabric.African nativity scenes are made by natives from pottery or carved from wood.Nativity scenes made from natural materials are very common – most often from palm leaves, corn husks or various dried fruits.Also interesting will be the videos that bring closer Advent, Christmas and New Year customs from many parts of the globe – for example from Spain, Italy, Iceland, China, Thailand, Japan, etc.
